body.p: GettysburgThis poem was published as “Gettysburg: July, 1863" in Harper’s New Monthly Magazine 33 (July 1866), 209, one of four other poems in Battle-Pieces to be previously published in that journal anonymously. [variation].

O pride of the days in prime of the months[allusion] July is the height of the summer. Now trebled[poetics] [double entendre] [allusion] Melville emphasizes the growing legacy of the battle, widely acknowledged as the turning point of the war, while alluding to the fact that the battle lasted three days. (Eric Meckley) in great renown, When before the ark of our holy cause[allusion] [biblical] Melville alludes to the Ark of the Covenant (as William Shurr notes) particularly as it figures in the Israelite clash with the Philistines in 1 Samuel 5 and their idol Dagon referenced in the next line of the poem. [poetics] [double entendre] Ark is also the name of the boat that Noah builds according to God's directions in Genesis 6-9 to save the animals and humanity from the flood sent to destroy the world because of human wickedness. The poem utilizes watery, nautical imagery throughout, and so this line also creates an image of the Union keeping the fate of humanity afloat against the destructive flood of the Confederate attack on the North. (Eric Meckley) Fell DagonDagon was an ancient Philistine fertility deity often associated with fish and depicted as a merman. This is in keeping with Melville's water imagery in the poem.
Dagon's fall after an encounter with the Israelites' Ark of the Covenant is depicted in 1 Samuel 5.
1 Samuel 5 King James Version (KJV)
5 And the Philistines took the ark of God, and brought it from Ebenezer unto Ashdod.
2 When the Philistines took the ark of God, they brought it into the house of Dagon, and set it by Dagon.
3 And when they of Ashdod arose early on the morrow, behold, Dagon was fallen upon his face to the earth before the ark of the Lord. And they took Dagon, and set him in his place again.
4 And when they arose early on the morrow morning, behold, Dagon was fallen upon his face to the ground before the ark of the Lord; and the head of Dagon and both the palms of his hands were cut off upon the threshold; only the stump of Dagon was left to him.
5 Therefore neither the priests of Dagon, nor any that come into Dagon's house, tread on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod unto this day.
(Eric Meckley) down— Dagon foredoomed, who, armed and targed[definition] [allusion] [military] [etymology] Targe is the Old English word for a small, round shield. Melville's coinage connotes Dagon carrying sword and shield. , Never his impious heart enlarged Beyond that hour; God walled his power, And there the last invader charged[allusion] [historical] The Union victory at Gettysburg deflected the only Confederate invasion of Northern territory undertaken in the war. (Eric Meckley).

He charged, and in that charge condensed His all of hate and all of fire[allusion] [historical] [military] Not only was the battle of Gettysburg the Confederacy's only major charge into the North, the turning point of the battle was Pickett's Charge, the failed attack focused on the Union center on July 3rd. (Eric Meckley); He sought to blast us in his scorn, And wither us in his ire. Before him went the shriek of shells— Aerial screamings, taunts and yells; Then the three waves[allusion] [historical] The three days of battle are depicted as waves crashing against the Union position, continuing the water imagery of the poem. (Eric Meckley) in flashed advance
Surged, but were met, and back they set: Pride was repelled by sterner pride, And Right is a strong-hold yet.

Before our lines it seemed a beach Which wild September gales have strown With havoc on wreck, and dashed therewith Pale crews unknown— Men, arms, and steeds. The evening sun Died on the face of each lifeless one, And died along the winding marge of fight And searching-parties lone.

Sloped on the hill the mounds were green, Our centre held that place of graves[allusion] [historical] The Union center was positioned along Cemetery Hill. (Eric Meckley), And some still hold it in their swoon, And over these a glory waves. The warrior-monument, crashed in fight, Shall soar transfigured in loftier light,In Melville's note "h" appended to the poem's title, describes a maker for a Federal officer killed in 1862 that was destroyed in the battle. The marker was restored during the consecration of the Gettysburg National Cemetery on July 4, 1865. (Eric Meckley) A meaning ampler bear; Soldier and priest with hymn and prayer Have laid the stone, and every bone Shall rest in honor there.
